title: Myron Healey
text:
Myron Daniel Healey (June 8, 1923 – December 21, 2005) was an American actor. He began his career in <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>, <a href="California">California</a> during the early 1940s and eventually made hundreds of appearances in movies and on television during a career spanning more than half a century.
Early years.
Healey was born in <a href="Petaluma%2C%20California">Petaluma</a> in <a href="Sonoma%20County%2C%20California">Sonoma County</a>, California, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Healey. He served in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> as an <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Corps">Air Corps</a> <a href="navigator">navigator</a> and <a href="Bombardier%20%28air%20force%29">bombardier</a>, flying in <a href="B-26%20Marauder">B-26</a> Martin Marauders in the <a href="European%20Theatre">European Theatre</a>. After the war he continued military duties, retiring in the early 1960s as a <a href="Captain%20%28OF-2%29">captain</a> in the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force%20Reserve">United States Air Force Reserve</a>.
Acting career.
Healey's film debut came in 1943 with "<a href="Young%20Ideas">Young Ideas</a>."
Returning to film work after the war, Healey played villains and henchmen in low-budget <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">Western</a> films. He also did some screenwriting. In the post-war period he was frequently seen in Westerns from <a href="Monogram%20Pictures">Monogram Pictures</a>, often starring <a href="Johnny%20Mack%20Brown">Johnny Mack Brown</a>, <a href="Jimmy%20Wakely">Jimmy Wakely</a> and <a href="Whip%20Wilson">Whip Wilson</a>.
In the 1950s Healey moved to more "bad guy" roles in other films, including the "<a href="Bomba%2C%20the%20Jungle%20Boy">Bomba</a>" and "<a href="Jungle%20Jim%20%28film%29">Jungle Jim</a>" series, crime dramas and more westerns. He portrayed the bandit <a href="Dalton%20Brothers">Bob Dalton</a> in an episode of the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="television%20series">television series</a> "<a href="Stories%20of%20the%20Century">Stories of the Century</a>", starring and narrated by <a href="Jim%20Davis%20%28actor%29">Jim Davis</a>. In 1955 he played a "good guy" for a change as <a href="Phyllis%20Coates">Phyllis Coates</a>' partner in the 1955 Republic Pictures serial "<a href="Panther%20Girl%20of%20the%20Kongo">Panther Girl of the Kongo</a>".
Earlier in 1952, Healey was cast in one of the first episodes of the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> television <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a>, "<a href="Death%20Valley%20Days">Death Valley Days</a>," hosted by the "Old Ranger" (<a href="Stanley%20Andrews">Stanley Andrews</a>). Healey played mining engineer Frank Johnson, a once-reluctant suitor who encounters his former love interest.
Healey appeared seven times as Capt. Bandcroft in "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Kit%20Carson">The Adventures of Kit Carson</a>" (1951–55). He was cast twice in 1957-58 as Becker in two episodes of the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>/<a href="Warner%20Brothers">Warner Brothers</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series "<a href="Colt%20.45%20%28TV%20series%29">Colt .45</a>" starring <a href="Wayde%20Preston">Wayde Preston</a>, seven times (1950–57) in the long-running "<a href="The%20Lone%20Ranger%20%28TV%20series%29">The Lone Ranger</a>", and ten times (1952–55) in "<a href="The%20Roy%20Rogers%20Show">The Roy Rogers Show</a>" television series.
Healey played the outlaw <a href="Johnny%20Ringo">Johnny Ringo</a> in the <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> <a href="television%20series">television series</a> "<a href="Tombstone%20Territory">Tombstone Territory</a>", with <a href="Pat%20Conway">Pat Conway</a> as Sheriff Clay Hollister, in the episode "Johnny Ringo's Last Ride" with a teleplay by <a href="Sam%20Peckinpah">Sam Peckinpah</a>. He appeared in an episode of the children's western series "<a href="Buckskin%20%28TV%20series%29">Buckskin</a>", which aired on NBC from 1958-59. He was a semi-regular on programs produced by <a href="Gene%20Autry">Gene Autry</a>'s "Flying A" production company: "<a href="Annie%20Oakley%20%28TV%20series%29">Annie Oakley</a>", "<a href="Buffalo%20Bill%2C%20Jr.">Buffalo Bill, Jr.</a>", "<a href="The%20Range%20Rider">The Range Rider</a>", and "<a href="The%20Gene%20Autry%20Show">The Gene Autry Show</a>". He also guest-starred on the crime drama with a modern Western setting, "<a href="The%20Sheriff%20of%20Cochise">The Sheriff of Cochise</a>", starring <a href="John%20Bromfield">John Bromfield</a>, and in the Western set in the 1840s, "<a href="Riverboat%20%28TV%20series%29">Riverboat</a>", starring <a href="Darren%20McGavin">Darren McGavin</a>. He also appeared in an episode of the second season of "<a href="Zorro">Zorro</a>."
Between 1960 and 1963, Healey appeared five times on the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> western "<a href="Laramie%20%28TV%20series%29">Laramie</a>", starring <a href="John%20Smith%20%28actor%29">John Smith</a> and <a href="Robert%20Fuller%20%28actor%29">Robert Fuller</a>. He appeared ten times on another NBC western, "<a href="The%20Virginian%20%28TV%20series%29">The Virginian</a>", and four times on "<a href="Laredo%20%28TV%20series%29">Laredo</a>". He also made appearances on "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>."
During the 1958-59 season Healey, billed as "Michael Healey", replaced <a href="Douglas%20Fowley">Douglas Fowley</a> as <a href="Doc%20Holliday">Doc Holliday</a> in the popular ABC/<a href="Desilu">Desilu</a> western series "<a href="The%20Life%20and%20Legend%20of%20Wyatt%20Earp">The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp</a>", starring <a href="Hugh%20O%27Brian">Hugh O'Brian</a> in the title role. Earlier, on September 25, 1956, Healey played the drunken gunfighter <a href="Clay%20Allison">Clay Allison</a> in an episode of the same name on "The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp".
From 1959 to 1961, he played Maj. Peter Horry, top aide to <a href="Leslie%20Nielsen">Leslie Nielsen</a>, in the <a href="miniseries">miniseries</a> "<a href="The%20Swamp%20Fox%20%28TV%20series%29">Swamp Fox</a>" on "<a href="Walt%20Disney%20Presents">Walt Disney Presents</a>", based on the <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">American Revolutionary War</a> hero <a href="Francis%20Marion">Francis Marion</a>.
In 1970 Healey appeared as Wardlow in the TV western "The Men From Shiloh" (the rebranded name of "<a href="The%20Virginian%20%28TV%20series%29">The Virginian</a>") in the episode titled "Jenny."
Collectively, Healey appeared in some 140 films, including 81 westerns and three serials. Among his non-western pictures, he appeared in at least two horror films: the Americanized version of the Japanese giant-monster movie "<a href="Varan%20the%20Unbelievable">Varan the Unbelievable</a>" (1958) and "<a href="The%20Incredible%20Melting%20Man">The Incredible Melting Man</a>" (1977).
Death.
In 2005, Healey broke his hip in a fall and never recovered. He died at the age of 82 at a hospital near his home in <a href="Simi%20Valley%2C%20California">Simi Valley, California</a>.
Recognition.
In 2000, Healey received a <a href="Golden%20Boot%20Awards">Golden Boot Award</a> for his contributions to Western films and television programs.
